name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
how was lnd affected? 

lnd uses this library to parse blocks we get from either the full node backend or p2p network, due to this bug lnd wasn't able to parse a new block, but was able to continue to forward as normal (synced_to_chain: false)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
the fix to btcd's wire parsing library can be found here: https://t.co/OOnbEn5aCy 

those running btcd nodes can apply this patch (an official release is forthcoming) and their nodes will accept the block as expected, since this wasn't a consensus issue

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: btcd's initial segwit v1 implementation correctly updated the consensus logic, but failed to also update the defense-in-depth check in the wire parsing layer (when parsing off the wire you want _some_ sort of upper limit)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: with segwit v1, this prior limit of the max accepted witness size was removed, in place of things like the sigop cost abstraction, effectively leaving the limit to the max block weight/size

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
so what happend? 

the issue was in btcd's wire parsing library that deserializes raw blocks, the initial implementation of segwit v0 included a consensus level check for witness size limits but _also_ hoisted this check up to the wire parsing layer

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
we've added a new `listaliases` RPC call that exposes all the current scid alias mappings 

check out these new docs for more information on using these new protocol features: https://t.co/ZqtWtNaGgf

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
scid aliases break the on-chain between a chan and identifier included in invoices (privacy++) 

they can be enabled independent of zero conf chans usage, we've also added an upgrade path for _existing_ chans, so if both peers upgrade then scid alises will be used automatically

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
by default to be safe, *all* incoming zero conf chan requests will be rejected

users will need to use the Channel Acceptor API (https://t.co/FSSwCk9w4h) to manually approve incoming zero conf channel requests

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
on the protocol side, this release includes support for zero conf + scid alias channels 

these can be enabled with two new flags: --protocol.option-scid-alias=true and --protocol.zero-conf=true

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
we also now default to using taproot addresses errwhere applicable, this means taproot change addrs are now used for: normal on chain sends, change addrs for channel funding, and also contract sweeps 

we'll also now use taproot addrs for co-op closes if the peers supports it

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @unitimpulse @rot13maxi @dusty_daemon reading a bit more, sounds like you're thinking of a case where an exchange or w/e issues assets to track user deposits, then publishes this (commitment openings) so 3rd parties can keep track of the amount of user deposits?

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@unitimpulse @rot13maxi @dusty_daemon for the ones that support on going issuance, there's an SMT that's stamped on-chain that tracks these outpoints 

a restriction can be made to have the output that commits to these always be the nth one in the OG issuance tx, this can be watched on chain for spends to track mints

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@unitimpulse @rot13maxi @dusty_daemon some assets will only ever be issued on time, for these you just use the tx that created them to know the supply

others can mark that they support future issuance by specifying a special key, that's used to sign future issuance -- for these you track a set of genesis outpoints

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@rot13maxi @unitimpulse @dusty_daemon in order for the receiver to recv in their specified asset, just like normal LN, they need that inbound

the outbound chan use use to satisfy the payment doesn't matter as long as you can send enough BTC into the final hop to satisfy the invoice

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @rot13maxi @unitimpulse @dusty_daemon re multi-hop: receiver hop says how much BTC to send into the last hop, any extra between that and the specified amount in the invoice can be considered part of an aggregate fee you deal w/ in a normal multi-hop scenario

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@rot13maxi @unitimpulse @dusty_daemon I think some stuff is getting confused here: liabilities is usually used for cases where there's explicit debt

for issued assets, you care about the total supply issued, this is stamped on chain in a structure that tracks all genesis outputs for the same key family (fungible)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @TheBlueMatt @lukechilds @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co it _does_ since w/ that you can assume the other peer will store the last commitment point so you can send to another peer, even after the channel has closed, the OG SCB relied on this behavior, and lnd will always store the last chan reest so it can always send

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @TheBlueMatt @lukechilds @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co is it a special message, or just setting a field in an existing one? ;)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@TheBlueMatt @lukechilds @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co I think it can work ok when there's already a trust anchor like acinq and the users of their wallet, but even then a mishap w/ the peer's backup can inadvertently lead to a breach (download, then force close, oops)

imo just closing out is much safer than trying to *resume*

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@TheBlueMatt @lukechilds @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co yeh I'm not really convinced that's better: how do you ensure they don't rollback (even inadvertently) to another state? also what would be the latency impact of the p2p ack+send for each state? 

might as well do replicated db stuff instead: you control the full pipeline

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@TheBlueMatt @lukechilds @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co it certainly isn't perfect, but if I had to do it all over again, I'd still do it, since it's saved countless users from a lot of misery over the years 

the only thing I'd change is prob adopting CLNs term of: emergency channel backup (a.k.a ECB ;)) since ppl don't like the name

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@TheBlueMatt @lukechilds @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co I wouldn't say that's a "unique message", but that's just semantics 

in any case, in *practice* our method here is deterministic way to trigger behavior defined in the spec, it's also saved a *ton* of BTC over the years that would've just rotted in the UTXO set

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@TheBlueMatt @lukechilds @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co it triggers this clause in the spec: 

> if next_commitment_number is not 1 greater than the commitment number of the last commitment_signed message the receiving node has sent:
> SHOULD send an error and fail the channel.

zero is used so if the chan hasn't been used it triggers

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@moneyball @lukechilds @umbrel @acinq_co before ppl had to do this all on the command line (SCB funds recovery) so nice that there's a UI that can handle it now 

the demos shows all chans going to "closing" state afterwards, main suggestion is prob more clearly signify that channels won't be resumed, be closed on chain

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@lukechilds @TheBlueMatt @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co matt our docs are *very* clear that this is to be used for disaster recovery

also w/ the current spec, chan reest is used to trigger a force close if a channel can't continue, there's a proposed change to switch to errors but that hasn't been merged: https://t.co/ssck9daSbc

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@TheBlueMatt @lukechilds @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co it's a disaster recovery mode that's designed to be hard to mess up (static once a chan has been created), live backups are hard for the typical user

ofc any peer can breach at any time, which is why lnd packages a watchtower client+server as part of the default node

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@TheBlueMatt @lukechilds @moneyball @umbrel @acinq_co what message are you talking about? the chan reest message? there's no special message we sent, everything is based on chan reest which is well defined in the spec

SCBs (which eclair and CL have an analogue of) just gives you enough info to send that and sweep on chain

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @milessuter @ercwl @nic__carter @LynAldenContact @moneyball puts a burden on all the implementation maintainers tho, since they need to release version to recognize the persistent forks so ppl can try to close out those channels or defend themselves

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@milessuter @ercwl @nic__carter @LynAldenContact @moneyball you'd need to play your channels on every "major" fork, thankfully we were able to launch LN only after all that fork drama subsided 

safest action would be close your chans on other forks, or if you're feeling devious: try to breach on the fork you care less about

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @milessuter @ercwl @nic__carter @LynAldenContact re the lack of protocol level ties, the jenga block effect on ETH is what creates such a strong dependency: everything is wound up and recycled several times over and ultimately dependent on a oracle or upstream custodian, their actions have ripple effects to all, systemic risk

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@milessuter @ercwl @nic__carter @LynAldenContact I think the same argument also applies to large centralized custodians: imagine there's a single party that held 80% of all the BTC, they'd have an outsized voice when it came down to forks or w/e

so the best defense is enabling more non-custodial apps/systems, not yo keys, etc

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@milessuter @ercwl @nic__carter @LynAldenContact fwiw there're already issued assets on BTC today, tho not in relative size 

I think things are diff w/ BTC: PoW is leaderless/pseudonymous, Taro is an overlay layer so there're aren't protocol/contract level ties to any of the assets, we've been thru segwit2x, we fork less

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@c_otto83 we like the feature bit, since nodes running a channel acceptor can accept/deny zero conf channels, whereas during it on accept (the resp) needs a channel acceptor acceptor or w/e

we have special cases for the implicit for LDK, but thought all impls were already setting that bit

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @c_otto83 this behavior is due to a sort of split w.r.t philosophy in the spec rn (documented in the PR and other issues), lnd prefers to explicitly negotiate zero conf using that feature bit (req) and the chan type (hence feature bit dep), while others prefer to send min_depth 0 (resp)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @c_otto83 for zero conf in particular we did a lot of manual tests against LDK+eclair since they were the first to have a branch for us to test against (we did some great interop tests IRL at the oakland summit)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@c_otto83 as you noted, this is an unreleased version of lnd

a few flavors of cross impls tests exist, but they haven't been maintained too much overtime causing them to atrophy, these days most stuff is done manually

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @c_otto83 also the test you modified is a bit more elaborate for the zero conf and scid mappings for forwarding, you can prob just modify the first TDD case in TestSkipIneligibleLinksMultiHopForward

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@c_otto83 you're right that rn the switch isn't able to distinguish between offline and totally unknown, a map stores all the active links

so to distinguish, need to either hit disk each forward to see if it's known but offline, or get notifications for opened/closed channels in real time

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
going a step further, you can also use the macaroons and lnd's RPC middleware interceptor to implement secure off-chain accounts (https://t.co/ePJPmgwWwp) 

so now when you owe Bob 15k sats, you can just give him a firewalled account sub-macaroon w/ access to only those funds

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: this enables flows like Twitch being able to add tips/subscriptions/interactions using LN, with them only gaining the slimmest possible permissions (can send 10k sats a day), with the user being able to revoke/demote the permissions at any time ü§Ø

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: 0.15.1 will also catch us up to version 0.4.0 of the musig2 draft BIP: https://t.co/uWWw5uo8Kb!

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
as usual, we've also made a slew of bug fixes and performance optimizations: https://t.co/sB16vKl2eQ

thanks to all the users that tested this release through it's long rc cycle and reported bugs!

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: this release also includes a slew of upgrades to the HTLC interceptor that LSPs and Lightning services have come to love including: support for sending a custom error message, an on chain HTLC hook, and a mode that always assume the interceptor is there

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: in the past, users have had issues w/ having several lnd nodes use ZMQ for block/txn notifications, with this new release we've added a new RPC polling mode for bitcoind (--bitcoind.rpcpolling) that should require less config tuning for multiplexing lnd nodes

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: we also now compile the mobile bindings w/ all the available sub-servers, which means that features like watchtowers, the new signing APIs, and the chain notifier (arbitrary chain event notifications) are now available for mobile applications üì±

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
on the mobile side, this release includes support for BIP 155, which allows neutrino to connect to tor v3 onion services 

neutrino also has a new sub-server that lets applications manually connect to peers, fetch blocks, and filters, etc: https://t.co/simyVDZZbk

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
early reports of the DB size reduction w/ this upcoming garbage collection migration are pretty impressive: https://t.co/Yewm2TtSEi

a user reported that their db size shrunk from 30 GB to 130 MB!!

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
in this release we've also addressed one of the biggest pain points larger nodes run into: db size growth 

the new release dramatically cuts down on db size growth (95% reduction) for _new_ channels

0.15.1 will contain an optional migration that removes all the _old_ state

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: at Lightning Labs we're already using all these new taproot features to upgrade Loop+Pool (and other new systems!) to take advantage of the chain space and fee savings, on top of the new designs space these features unlock

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
one of the coolest things in the release is a new experimental musig2 API: https://t.co/uxcqeGg4EI

the API is intended to be developer friendly, as all the signing state is managed via interaction with a musig2 "session"

it's marked as experimental given the BIP isn't final

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
the PSBT related calls (FundPsbt+SignPsbt) should now "just work" for taproot, as we're able to populate/verify all the new BIP 371 related fields 

the PSBT flow supports signing for BIP 86 addrs, keyspend paths, and also script spend paths

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
the set of signing related calls (SignOutputRaw, etc) has gained a new SignMethod field: https://t.co/BwhtOYhA6W

using this field, along w/ some of the new prevout fields (taproot needs all inputs to sign sighash all), users are able to generate BIP 340/342 signatures

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
taproot addrs can now be created on the command line with: lncli newaddress p2tr 

lnd's seed format (aezeed) has had is internal version bumped to 1, to reflect that these new addrs may include taproot outputs, an offline tool can be used to allow users to "upgrade" their seed

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: w/ this release lnd further cements itself as *the* developer's platform for Bitcoin+Lightning application development üõ†: https://t.co/DRfAbxcHfr

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun

as usual, we recommend that all users update!

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@theinstagibbs @SomsenRuben @brqgoo to some degree likely, but Bitcoin doesn't mine invalid transactions and you can't modify the behavior of a transaction by shifting the order of other transactions in front of it that don't spend the same UTXO thankfully

ofc a lot of funny biz can be done by miners today w/ LN

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@SomsenRuben @theinstagibbs @brqgoo chains of UTXO transactions have stronger binding since invalid transactions can't be mined, and also there're strict parent/child dependancies 

which means less shenanigans all around, also until information is revealed it looks like any other transaction , so sniping is harder

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@SomsenRuben @theinstagibbs @brqgoo eh imo not to the same extent: account oriented chains don't have strong ordering guarantees w.r.t transaction inclusion, transactions can be re-ordered at will which can make them fail/modify their behavior, and they still get mined and pay chain fees

enables sandwiches etc

tweet: For those in Miami, I'll be at the bitdevs meet up later today to explain more and answer any questions! ‚ö°Ô∏èüå¥

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: This design retains the network effects of the Lightning Network, as more demand of asset transfers ‚û° more routing activity ‚û° more routing revenue ‚û° increase demand for LN capacity ‚û° mo LN. This solidifies LN as the world's instant value transaction layer ‚ö°Ô∏èüåç

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: Instead, internal nodes will just see normal LN payments as normal, as the assets only exist at the edge of the network. This enables us to re-use the existing liquidity in the Bitcoin backbone of the network, and means a new network doesn't need to be bootstrapped for each asset

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: Most importantly (!!) the Taro design enables a series of extensions to the base LN protocol (BOLTs), which will allow for multi-hop transfers of assets, using the existing Bitcoin backbone of the LN. By deploying assets only at the edges, internal nodes don't need to upgrade

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: Future versions of the Taro VM can begin to add new functionality such as new op codes (maybe even covenants!) to further increase the expressibility at the Taro asset script layer

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: The first version of the Taro embedded scripting system uses the existing Bitcoin Script Taro VM to construct a virtual transaction (1-in-1-out) which uses the input+output MS-SMT tree roots to bind the validation context. This design route enables re-use of all existing tooling

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: Taro supporst normal+collectible assets. Normal assets can be split/merged similar to Bitcoin UTXOs, and re-use the merkle sum property to ensure no assets r inflated during transfers. Taro also supports collectible assets which are indivisible (1-of-1 hologrpahic beefzard cards)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: Taro uses a new data structure I call a Merkle Sum Sparse Merkle tree which combines the properties of a merkle sum tree along with a Sparse Merkle Tree to construct commits that enable 3rd party supply/balance verification and also efficient proofs of non-inclusion

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
I'm soo excited to finally publicly publish a set of draft BIPs for Taro, a Taproot Asset Representation Overlay: https://t.co/2naeQhyJ6V

Taro uses the Taproot script tree to commit to extra structure metadata which enables the representation and transfer of assets on Bitcoin

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@callebtc @rot13maxi @L0laL33tz the bitcoin p2p one? afaict, both: it uses a technique that makes pubkeys indistinguishable from random bytes, but also mentions traffic shaping and decoy traffic

my TODO there is talking about timing/sizing, LN p2p is already encrypted, but doesn't use something like elligator

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @rot13maxi @L0laL33tz a solution in this domain (diff context re adversary monitoring links to trace payments) would likely borrow a lot from loopix, re periodically sending self payments, but loopix relies on a planned network arch: https://t.co/nt08TU5tBW

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @rot13maxi @L0laL33tz in the LN domain, things are a bit more complex as an adversary can route targeted payments through your node, sure we could impl sending random data like that TODO, but we'd have no idea if it actually worked, so extraordinary claims about added privacy need equiv analysis

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@rot13maxi @L0laL33tz I'm not saying it's impossible, but it's very hard in practice, and even harder to determine if things actually work, ofc it also depends on your threat model and adversary 

an old paper on the topic worth reading: https://t.co/CjyzgHlb94

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @rot13maxi @L0laL33tz not to mention the fact that an observer can inject their own traffic (in the form of transactions they make) to attempt to categorize/cluster nodes, today most nodes do some randomization w.r.t tx broadcast order, but there exists no meta-analysis w.r.t how effective it is

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@rot13maxi @L0laL33tz stuff like this is part of the intuition behind the anon trilemma: if all nodes sent 4 MB/s (random value) at all times to all other peers, then this extra bandwidth may help to hide this traffic pattern

this comes at the cost of more bandwidth, making it harder to run a node

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@rot13maxi @L0laL33tz hard to overstate the "perfectly uniformly" criteria in my tweet, consider that Bitcoin nodes are essentially one giant clock: every 10 mins, a network observer can expect a burst of traffic (new block)

hiding that traffic pattern means all nodes need to expend equiv bandwidth

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @acinq_co @alexbosworth you're right in that the very first version (which was just a list of nodes for our now deprecated mobile app to connect to) ACINQ wasn't included, but that was just due to a bug related to interaction of the system where the easy fix was to ignore some nodes

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@niftynei in practice, nodes may tend to bias towards more reliable nodes, similar to when routing HTLCs many path finding impls today attach some probability of success and decrease/increase that accordingly

seems like a nice gig tho: keep shuffling bytes and you'll keep getting paid!

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@niftynei seems similar to trying to figure out who held an HTLC...tho in this case retries/triangulations are easier since no HTLC is involved 

so assuming I do some go-back-n thing and have the receiver ACK each message, on timeout I try diff route subset

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@niftynei if we more tightly coupled the data transfer to HTLC payment transfer then seems to mitigate it further

but then we're back to shoving more data in HTLCs (beyond necessary routing info) which is what onion messaging tries to step away from

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@niftynei since the data isn't being revealed/forward on chain, doesn't seem to be a good way to 100% guarantee the exchange happens (the same way we can if the data was the pre-image of an HLTC) 

if a node takes the 50 sat payment (or w/e) doesn't do anything, you stop using them

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @niftynei yeh good observation, proposed mitigation there is to do it in sort of an iterated tit-for-tat basis: you pay for a small amount first (lets say you're just doing invoices so nothing too large), then ramp up based on succesful forwards

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: it's opt in on top of normal onion messaging feature bit signalling, so some nodes can choose to only forward for a payment while others choose to forward for free (similar to existing altruistic zero fee nodes that already exist)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
onion messaging is kept mostly unchanged, w/ nodes now needing to store info per session (40 bytes) and perform some additional bandwidth accounting before forwarding 

with this scheme, nodes gain a new revenue source alongside normal payments w/ the spam issue being handled

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
I just published a proposal to add bandwidth metered payments to onion messages: https://t.co/FJXPlTk13l

AMP along with a new onion_session_id value is used to allow senders to purchase forwarding bandwidth and for receivers to accept/deny sessions a single step

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@JeremyRubin @n1ckler @reardencode @lopp @pwuille when computing the top-level output key, it's already possible to have some across a block be even and others odd (result of a tweak), so control block encodes that info and you check when validating the commitment 

this pops up in bip 32 as well IIUC: https://t.co/Vl8HFryzrl

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@JeremyRubin @n1ckler @reardencode @lopp taproot keys are 32-bytes until you need to manipulate them, then that extra bit either needs to be explicitly encoded (like in the control block) or worked around 

might be too early to call, but: is the 1 byte savings in the pkScript worth the added protocol/code overhead?

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@ProofOfKeags @ercwl pure channels make a similar uptime assumption, but one that's distributed over the entire network (no SPoF like current rollup), and add the path constraints 

up side is you don't pay marginal chain fees for each transaction, actually instant, decentralized, can send small amts

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@ProofOfKeags @ercwl right now all roll ups are centralized: they have a single party that accepts transactions and has complete control over sequencing, so you depend on them for availability 

up sides is you can send to ppl w/o them doing chain interaction first, and there're no bal constraints

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@ProofOfKeags @ercwl roll ups post all data on chain, assume it's valid, and use challenges to prove if invalid, as a result each transaction has a marginal on-chain cost, which is affected by the on-chain fee market 

in addition, transactions take time to clear (need block confs), so not "instant"

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @rusty_twit @realtbast @TheBlueMatt +1, I think the odd rule and feature bits in most places are compatible, feature bits will let us eventually *only* use explicit funding which is superior from an API perspective imo: the user *knows* which channel they'll get, no surprises

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

along the way we found other edge cases w.r.t downgrading from explicit to implicit that we want to clarify in the spec

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

tweet: @arush @ercwl I think you'd also want to add a builtin in the CPU for sighash calculation, then if that can preferentially commit to certain fields, it's able bind a valid proof to a certain transaction structure

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@arush @ercwl since it's CPU AIR based, there aren't really any "wires" anymore, but assuming it's possible to create some bootstrap state as part of first output that is a commitment to starting memory

still getting thru the latest Cairo paper fwiw, these are just early ideas

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@arush @ercwl so then in theory possible to combine other outputs that commit to diff state types and make new outputs which are result of state transition function on state

ideally lots of ppl are "in" these outputs to take advantage of STARK proof aggregation and amortization

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @arush @ercwl so there's state, but it's just committed to in each output, proof asserts knowledge and structure of valid state, state never really exposed on chain but maintained on the side

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@arush @ercwl can be based off a partial application of state, so we bind the set of possible state transitions from an initial point

so you'd commit to current state in the output, and use proofs that are based on partial application of the "wires" to implement on chain zk state machines

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@arush @ercwl idea isn't that it itself enables covenants, but that the tap script leaves allow for new script updates w/o a new top level segwit output type

re state, assuming it's possible to commit to (a commitment of?) to the current state taproot tree, then in theory the STARK proof...

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @rusty_twit @RyanTheGentry @cycryptr @ImperviousAi this composition means a loop out swap type never really "fails" as the sender just pushes as much over as they can, then completes share reconstruction w/ a 1 mSAT HTLC (or w/e is the smallest HTLC they can send over)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@rusty_twit @RyanTheGentry @cycryptr @ImperviousAi atomicity also allows for composition of payment types

in the context of Loop, composing AMP+PTLC lets us create a new Loop Out type that allows sender to push "as much as they can", while still making it fully atomic ( point used for on-chain HTLC, combined w/ root point/share)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@rusty_twit @RyanTheGentry @cycryptr @ImperviousAi also I don't think you've thought thru this notion that no applications rely on payment atomicity 

in this context, the atomicity of AMP is what lets the sender cancel transfer all together (send an invalid share) or decide to end the stream early (root share as encryption key)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @rusty_twit @RyanTheGentry @cycryptr @ImperviousAi yeh they can also be composed with AMP (to make them spontaneous), payment types aren't a zero sum game, odd to treat it as such given all type have their own tradeoffs, here's a refresher from conner's talk at LNConf: https://t.co/HErvACKbIv

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @rusty_twit @RyanTheGentry @cycryptr @ImperviousAi the extra set_id identifier also lets a receiver correlate payments to the same payment_addr as well, which can be useful for periodic/ongoing payment pushes

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @rusty_twit @RyanTheGentry @cycryptr @ImperviousAi re-using payment hashes (MPP) means you need to wrangle with the partial payment issue (funds not fully delivered) if a shard gets pulled early for some reason, sure you can do it but why not make each shard indistinguishable from another (AMP) and improve privacy + make atomic?

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @stefanwouldgo @embarrassedOK @renepickhardt @lopp @c_otto83 https://t.co/Eko4leKee1

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@lopp @renepickhardt @c_otto83 like other domains, at times it can be good enough to just use some approximate value to start w/ (like lnd does), then greedily iterate to what will actually *work* in practice 

base fee ensures you always get paid, and helps you shape traffic (based on sender's fee limits)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@lopp @renepickhardt @c_otto83 it may make it easier to attempt to find the *optimal* path splits, but at the trade off of significantly more computational resources than a greedy algo (30 min run time in the paper)

in practice, you don't need optimal, just good enough since things are so dynamic anyway

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@BTC_LN @renepickhardt since at times the proportional value is zero, the base fee is what ensures you earn w/ each forward 

theoretical results are cool, but w/ stuff like this usually some approximate/greedy solution is enough since you want to quickly iterate+update thru attempts

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@BTC_LN @renepickhardt dropping your base fee doesn't do anything atm to improve path finding for senders, in theory it makes the problem easier to optimize, but in practice you don't care about the optimal and only what works in practice 

the base fee has a role in that it ensures you always get paid

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@jackmallers @Nakadai_mon @1stRdK0 @VikingoBitcoin1 @Bitcoinbeach a quick way to check if a zero value invoice is safe or not is looking at the set of feature bits from a decoded invoice: https://t.co/WN7l1yvh28 

if 14 (the payment addr required bit) is set, then the receiver will reject the payment if the payment addr isn't included

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@jackmallers @Nakadai_mon @1stRdK0 @VikingoBitcoin1 @Bitcoinbeach since lnd v0.12.0 (released in Jan), all payments to newly created invoices requires the payment addr/secret to be included in the onion for the final hop: https://t.co/6WecVPq3vi

this value can't be guessed by intermediate nodes, so zero-value invoices can be used safely

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@RobertSpigler @JeremyRubin CSFS w/ any partial application covenant gives you nearly arbitrary delegation of outputs, combine that with the fact the taproot outputs are just pubkey and you also get arbitrary script delegation a la graftroot

some overlap is unavoidable imo, just like many ways to write x86

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @RobertSpigler @JeremyRubin some stack based covenant with op_cat let's you do things like construct expected pkScripts to transition to based on input data, taproot makes it a bit harder tho since you'd need basic EC ops as well, but we already do a ton when validating sigs, so not much worse imo

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@RobertSpigler @JeremyRubin op_cat and CSFS lets you do stuff like have an MPC transcript that results in a signed output (generated by the MPC) with script enforcing diff payout structures (secure computation with penalties) based on structured msgs

it's all additive really

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @RobertSpigler @JeremyRubin CSFS also gives another way to implement replacement by sequence for off-chain update structures (like eltoo), but with no_input added then off-chain structures are generally more flexible

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@RobertSpigler @JeremyRubin only really limited by your imagination, one example is being able to create a tournament style coin flip lottery off-chain with a closed or open set of participants 

even with convenants that support partial input application ctv is useful for things like congestion ctrl txns

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@RobertSpigler @JeremyRubin they also all allow distinct functionality as well, op_cat and no_input aren't at odds anymore than no_input and op_ctv are, the more enhancing primitives the better

things aren't zero sum ("nextism" is to be avoided imo)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: stuff like mini script helps to optimize the "size" of the circuit components, but higher levels tools like Sapio are needed to permit transaction level templating a.k.a actual smart contract design in the UTXO model

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
one can think of it like being able to specify a merklezied transaction execution graph

so a circuit where the gates are txns and wires r the set of possible state transitions

smart contract design in the UTXO model is functional by nature (pure funcs, just inputs and outputs)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

you're right tho in that 100% mass withdrawals are still an issue

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @zack_bitcoin the idea here is to have a very fast and low cost way for an individual to join the system (w/ a marginal amt of on-chain transactions is zero), while maintaining a "good enough" claim on a corresponding on-chain output as they aren't in the root multi-sig

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@ProofOfKeags yep, in its absence, you're forced to do more interactive and pre-signing (w/ extra storage)

what I have in mind re O(1) space complexity is a covenant variant that allows partial application of func params, so you don't need to enumerate all participants and state transitions

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: had a key insight the other week (maybe others have already noticed) that w/ taproot we can upgrade the security of off-chain channel creation from a "2-of-3" security model, to something that gives entrants a claim on an eventual unrolled UTXO in a participant tree, batched ofc

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: w/ current capabilities, the best we can do is logarithmic space complexity for the UTXO unrolling, w/ a few additional base script enhancements, constant space complexity is possible

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
if we're to bring Bitcoin to a billion people, it's a fundamental constraint that everyone *cannot* posses a claim to a root UTXO

therefore, it's imperative that we build protocols that allow secure off-chain channel creation w/ unilateral withdraw via root UTXO tree unrolling

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @send_bitcoins @bitconner @matt_odell those invoices can only really be used once, if two people pay it, then one of them gets there "first" which reveals the payment pre-image within the network, this means if someone else tries to pay it then their payment may not actually get all the way there

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @andreneves @bitconner yeah it can be used w/ variable amounts (just set zero value in the invoice), min+max isn't defined in the format rn but can easily be added w/ new TLV records in the invoice

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @Snyke @urza_cc @kiwiidb @bitconner @rusty_twit they're related but serve diff uses cases IMO: AMP is for when you just need to fling something to the other side and the payment addr is all the context you need, Offers is for when you need more involved negotiation like deciding on a rate for fiat conversion, etc, etc

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @nadahalli @realtbast @joostjgr moving to something like HORNET would also help x-put on the forwarding plane as it has no asymmetric crypto operations when nodes are forwarding (just symmetric crypto), which showed up pretty heavily in joost's flame graphs

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @nadahalli @realtbast @joostjgr also keep in mind that rn the current HTLC in-flight limit (to allow all HTLCs to be breach remedied in a single transaction) puts an upper bound on x-put, it can be 3x'd or so w/o running into policy level limits, beyond that a tree structure can be used like indirect blocks

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @nicolasburtey @StephaneBres @bottlepay @joostjgr the other thing with bolt is that it never reclaims disk space automatically when things are deleted, so the size on disk is the *largest* the DB has ever been, compaction is needed to reclaim space rn it's manual, can be made automatic in the future

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @openoms @dstadulis FWIW that was run using an in-memory file system IIRC ( tempfs)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@theinstagibbs @Suheb__ @joostjgr also the disk requirements for just *forwarding nodes* are pretty diff than sender+receiver, since they just need to keep track of the HTLC circuit 

receiver would want to keep all invoices, etc for accounting purposes likely, but that can be stores elsewhere outside the daemon

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @theinstagibbs @Suheb__ @joostjgr yeah there're a ton of low hanging fruits for both disk and throughput optimization, wasn't really a top prio a few years ago, but with increasing usage may make sense to start plucking the ones that we've known about forever

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@benthecarman @Suheb__ @joostjgr for example for each invoice we store the set of HTLCs that settled that invoice, it's set of custom records, etc, etc 

not needed for minimal operation, but nice to be able to see how the payment was split to arrive at your node, etc

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @benthecarman @Suheb__ @joostjgr us keeping around the prior states in tact on disk is just an implementation decisions, it lets use easily scan the past states to get balance snapshots, but minimally you just need the HTLC diff and shachain state then you can brute force most of the rest

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@Suheb__ @joostjgr re eltoo: prob wouldn't make a big difference since HTLCs are all involved 

it comes down in the end to the persistence scheme used, there's a 4 year old lnd issue w/ an idea to impl a custom file format for the state machine: https://t.co/j49IciNNWi

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
ran this on my laptop (M1) and got pretty diff results, only let it run to 10k but got:
 * lnd-bbolt: 170 TPS
 * c-lightning: 71 TPS

so YMMV depending on what hardware it's run on, nevertheless nice to have a basic easy to run benchmarking suite!

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@Suheb__ @joostjgr even just from the PoV of HTLCs, they're each 1.3 KB so 1 mil of them on disk is 6.5GB w/o accounting storage overhead 

we don't need them after things are fully processed along w/ a lot of other things that can be pruned out, also bolt doesn't reclaim disk space automatically

  * explorers don't show definitive info of initial broadcast time nor the OG fee used for broadcast

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@serg_tikhomirov @lightning we plan on improving the transparency/verifiability of the chain by creating an off-chain updated merkle root of the chain that'll be stamped as part of each block 

before some fancy ZK proof type thing, this would let users publish proofs of the server ignoring orders

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@serg_tikhomirov @lightning as "misbehaving" shadowchain orchestrator in this context is the same as it just always being offline

in that case, similar to a payment channel, the user can "exit" the chain by waiting for the CLTV duration

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @serg_tikhomirov so in this case, a "valid" client would sign its inputs for an invalid batch, it verifies both the "state transition" as well as the structure of the batch transaction itself (proper chain fee split, my account and leases are there, etc)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
rn traders post the max fee rate they're ok w/, and the auctioneer filters out orders w/ a fee rate below its target

we plan to move to a system where everyone pays a low fee rate (say 1 sat/byte), batch then can be bumped via CPFP for those that want quicker conf, fee sponsors

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
each batch execution transaction spends all the account inputs involved, and creates outputs of:
  * the updated accounts of each maker+taker, premium paid+accrued along w/ their fee share of the batch transaction 
  * the funding outputs of each of the purchased channel leases

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
the first auction batch in the public mainnet for Lightning Pool was just executed! 

https://t.co/3HxQoKAkb1

those already running `poold` locally can get more info using: 

pool auction snapshot --batch_id=03a105b52989847be6f4e262d255d3ff7575552a9c0616838d560c702f9a6e43f5

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @scamwickfade @hasufl side-car channels actually also let you withdraw _into_ a brand new channel: https://t.co/XRRcvjGtuR

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @beeforbacon1 there's also some other fun stuff that can be built on top of that concept ;)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@beeforbacon1 good q! rn it's a one time payment

we plan to make this into streaming interest (paid out per block) using something we call "coupon channels", basically a new sub uni-directional channel for coupon payments

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: side-car channels solve another boostrapping issue as they allow Carol who has no funds on Lighting (and maybe no bitcoin!) to be onboarded onto the network in a single transaction, several of these onboarding can also be batched in the same transaction!

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: one other cool feature of the system is that it presents the first (?) working version of what's been referred to as "side-car" channels, they allow a Alice (the taker) to purchase a new chanenl (with both inbound+outbound bandwidth) for her friend Carol from Bob (the maker)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: those that run Lighting Terminal can update to the latest release which already packages in all the new hotness of Pool: https://t.co/GUKzLdn3FZ

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
those that want to get started should check out our developer documentation: https://t.co/DpYY0o9Pob

and also join the #pool channel on our developer slack!

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: "dual-funding" can also effectively be simulated using Pool, simply by placing a similar ask+bid order in order to obtain both inbound and outbound bandwidth in a single transaction!

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: the batch execution transaction also means the auction may potentially be a cheaper way to open channels, as your coin selection is simplified (single UTXO), and the channel output itself is split fee-wise between the maker+taker

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: blocks in the system can be "compressed" off-chain via an interactive block cut-thru protocol, meaning we can summarize several logical shadowchain blocks into a single bitcoin transaction

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @paddypisa check out our shadowchain architecture, I had the same insight that led to the creation of it: https://t.co/tZM0jphL47

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: this account mapped onto UTXOs structure means we avoid complex exit games, fraud proofs, unrolls, etc as the user remains in control of their funds at all times and only needs to validate shadowchain blocks that it's involved in

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
the version of lifted UTXOs we use in the shadowchain are a 2-of-2 time-lock release multi-sig script between the auctioneer and the user

this structure allows the users to regain the coins at any time, yet commits them to new blocks added to the shadowchain with sign off

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
accounts in the system are non-custodial and utilize a pattern we call a "Lifted UTXO" in the paper

the structure means the system is fully non-custodial, and users fully verify all operations of the auctioneer via the shadowchain block proposal/execution technique

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
each auction clearing dervives a *per-block* interest rate for each duration bucket which repreesnts the current lease rate of capital on the Lighting Network 

auction batches are executed in a single atomic transaction that creates new channels and updates the set of accounts

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
channel leases have a few base params: amt, duration, per-blocks interest rate

there're distinct auctions run for reach duration "bucket", at launch we have a single bucket of 2016 blocks, with more buckets (4032, 6048, etc) following later

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
Pool allows users to buy and sell lightning channels packaged in a form we call as "channel lease"

channel leases allow those that need inbound liquidity to purchase it in the marketplace, paying out a premium to the maker, with the lifetime of the channel enforced by Script

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
Lightning Pool is a non-custodial, sealed-bid, periodic batch auction that uses a uniform clearing price market clearing rule 

Pool leverages a new application overlay framework for Bitcoin we call a "Shadowchain" that scales via an interactive block-thru protocol

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @PrepareToBlend @junderwood4649 @bitconner @aantonop @lightning "careful engineering" here really means "path dependence"

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @PrepareToBlend @junderwood4649 @bitconner @aantonop @lightning there's this old compatibility matrix on bitcointalk that shows the gap between the ideal "universal seed phrase" and the reality

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: @PrepareToBlend @junderwood4649 @bitconner @aantonop @lightning there're several other advantages of aezeed over any other seed format, in the end you should only really expect the same wallet that you received the seed phrase from to be able to recovery it properly

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@PrepareToBlend @junderwood4649 @bitconner @aantonop @lightning aezeed doesn't actually have a word list, bip39 works by _hashing_ the actual _words_ to derive a seed, meaning you can't use the same seed for an English vs Japanese wallet 

with aezeed, the encrypted payload is _encoded_ using an arbitrary word list, the mapping is reversible

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
mining pools are starting to offer Lightning-based payouts! 

by paying out over LN, they can safe space in their produced blocks as all the numerous smaller payouts can instead be executed off-chain, not to mention the floor on payout size can be lowered

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: going even further, the ability to swap out channel types on the fly adds yet another level of extensibility which'll allow LN to continue to evolve in order to support new use cases and functionality (there won't be one channel type to rule them all)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: the upcoming taproot soft-fork dramatically increases the design space of channels in general, dynamic commitments would let us just update the multi-sig output first, roll that out, then later design new channel types that take advantage of all the new tools available

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: beyond updating to new safer channel formats, this may allow nodes to re-negotiate certain channel params on the fly (such as the # of outstanding HTLCs allowed)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
thankfully (!!), it's possible to upgrade the _entire network_ to newer safe channel types in a de-synced manner using this on-the-fly channel update mechanism

the upcoming anchor outputs commitment format (which future increases safety) can use this as well

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
however the up-take of this new safer channel format has lagged since atm, in order to upgrade to a new channel type, you're forced to _close_ out your existing channel

updating all the channels in the network w/ this mechanism would result in tens of thousands of on-chain txns

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet: so far in the history of LN, post-deployment, we've changed the channel type once to make certain types of recovery safer by having force closed funds be sent directly to the key of the remote party (static_remote_key)

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
dynamic commitments, or upgrading channels w/o any on-chain transactions: https://t.co/AcNJVNwC4P

in the post I describe a protocol extension that would allow nodes to swap out commitment/channel types _on the fly_, providing the network w/ a new desynchronized update mechanism

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
@francispouliot_ rn the set payload for AMP (sharded keysend): shard amt, total atm, payment addr (obtained from QR code or blank, can be used as a uuid or account ID), set ID (unique for each payment in shard) 

beyond that other info can be attached too, prob the first ppl will go for is a memo

name: Olaoluwa Osuntokun
tweet:
